setup.question: Why was the main character daydreaming about being a war-time pilot?
answers: He was obsessed with magazines about the subject
He was actually there and the memories were real

Text.text: No matter what, it's clear that the narrator is obsessed with war mags, so much so that the man who he buys them from even calls him out on it:
'until sweat starts rolling off the end of their nose', which is important because our protag later displays this exact same obsessive behavior to seeing more wartime mags:

Context: At first, it seems as if he travels back in time. But after realizing his memories & the reality he sees are messed up, he seeks help. The twist is that he had an operation for youth/immortality that fractured his mind, and thus the 'fake' memories are actually real (Proof 1: Dr. talking about operation:
His obsession with magazines is because he won't let go of the past. He even says that his obsession was ridiculous as foreshadowing, proof 2:

I'm leaning B very slightly bc this would be a spectacular lie to make up. I'm assuming you both will want to heavily counter each other. My questions:
1. To A: Do you agree with the context/recap? If not, provide your own. If you do, then it seems like you'd need to prove that the protagonist wasn't there in real life. Proceed with rebutting everything B said. 
2. To B: So is your argument that the protagonist was originally there, and this somehow _caused_ the unhealthy magazine obsession? Was he daydreaming before/independent of the magazines?

Judge, B has agreed that mc is obssessed with mags, honestly should end the debate there. 

Also, mc is just nostalgic, he even says so himself:
This is his reaction to B's ev about the pilots:
proving that he's just an obsseive personality, not that he was there. Again, the question itself contradicts B's elaborate lie - it literally says daydreaming.

Yes judge, my argument is that he was actually there that's why he's daydreaming about being a pilot and obsessed with the era in general. I don't have to disagree that he's obsessed with magazines, just that it's not the answer

More context: The bookshop is the past life trigger. He then daydreams of being a war pilot, then wakes up in what seems like a different era. And it isn't clear whether he is in reality or faked memories or daydreaming:
When Dr. reveals the truth the character says

Feels like the common case of the 'simple' answer and the 'more info' answer being the reason for the simple one. What A says in c.1685 could fall into this narrative too. I buy the connection between c.1245 and c.6848 and A didn't push back more strongly on what should I think be an easy lie to pick apart. Going for B, also just to get a resolution on a pending debate. If I get it wrong I'm gonna (incorrectly) blame the time lag :P

answers.other factors: I definitely dropped the ball here and got back to judging the debate after a few weeks. I think my reasoning was fine but I would maybe have asked for another turn if I was doing this in sync
answers.reason for outcome: It fit a common pattern where the incorrect answer is kind of a dumbed down version of the more complex but correct answer. I had earlier asked the dishonest debater to clap back against what would've been an extraordinary lie and they failed to do so, which made my decision easier.
I won even though the Q was pretty hard bc I gave the plot twist context needed. Judge should've added round for confidence?

Text.text: Context: At first, it seems as if he travels back in time. But after realizing his memories and the reality he sees is wrong, he seeks help. The twist is that he had an operation to be youthful and immortal that fractured his mind, and thus the 'fake' memories are actually real.

Most minds can't stand being young (68256832)We use synapse-shift to switch your (68486854)memories (68566857)You remember only those things out of the past you have to, to retain your identity. (68696887) While he was obsessed with the magazines, it was because they provided him with comfort from the past that he remembers, and he even says that his obsession with the magazines was ridiculous as foreshadowing.
